Kraleva a ⁎ H. Lund a J. Weiß a S. Bartling a H. Atia a Z. Cherkezova-Zheleva b D. Paneva b S. Wohlrab a U. G. Bonchev Str., Sofia 1113, Bulgaria Institute of Catalysis, BAS-BG Acad. G. Bonchev Str. Sofia 1113 Bulgaria Institute of Catalysis, BAS-BG, Acad. G. Bonchev Str., 1113 Sofia, Bulgaria ⁎ Correspondence to: Leibniz-Institut für Katalyse e.V. Albert-Einstein-Straße 29a, 18059, Rostock. Leibniz-Institut für Katalyse e.V. Albert-Einstein-Straße 29a Rostock 18059 To improve the CO2-to-light olefin process in terms of economics, efficient catalysts are essential to maximize the yield. Our research was carried out on FeAlCuK, which is still considered as a benchmark for olefin formation via CO2 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS). Nevertheless, the effect of various activation conditions on the formation of desired active species and final activity of this catalyst has not been described in literature to date. We studied the pretreatment by varying both the reduction gas and temperature. The catalyst was pretreated with pure H2 or synthesis gas (H2/CO = 3) to identify the bulk and surface species formed in each case. We demonstrate that the FeCuAlK catalyst should be activated in a H2/CO atmosphere at 250 °C for 4 h before the test at typical FTS reaction conditions to reach maximum productivity. The reduction with H2/CO led to the formation of active Fe5C2 and Fe3O4 phases producing a high fraction of light olefins at higher CO2 conversion. The role of promoters K and Cu was also investigated. Selectivity for desired C2-C4 olefins increased by 10 % compared to catalysts which were used directly in FTS without preliminary activation. Characterization with ex and in situ powder X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, and XPS after each activation treatment as well as Mössbauer spectroscopy revealed a strong impact of gas nature on the phase composition which was correlated with the performance. Graphical Abstract Keywords FeCuAlK Pre-treatment Light olefins CO2 hydrogenation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene, propylene and butenes are important building blocks in the chemical industry. They are essential for the production of polymers, plastics or synthetic textiles, lubricants, cleaning agents, solvents and cosmetics [1]. Moreover, they can also serve as precursors for liquid fossil fuels such as gasoline, diesel and jet fuel [2]. These light olefins can be produced by steam cracking of naphtha, fluid catalytic cracking of vacuum residues, direct/indirect synthesis gas conversion (CO + H2), or by hydrogenation of CO2 [3]. The latter (ideally renewable) route can be categorised into four groups, namely methanol to olefins (MTO), ethanol to olefins (ETO), dimethyl ether to olefins (DMTO) and Fischer-Tropsch syntheses (FTO [4]). Generally, methods that are not based on crude oil are very interesting for the chemical industry, as they could mitigate global climate change caused by the gradual increase in CO2 emissions into the atmosphere [5–7]. However, it is also important to keep the processes that involve a carbon cycle simple. The classical Fischer-Tropsch process for the production of olefins is based on a one-step reaction that consumes synthesis gas without adjusting the H2/CO ratio [8]. This might make FTO more cost-efficient compared to the others, however, suitable conditions must be found that allow CO2 to be used directly as a feedstock. For FTS using syngas as feedstock, iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co) are used as active metals in industrial catalysts. Since their oxides are inactive for the reaction, the solids must undergo an activation treatment to obtain the actual Fischer-Tropsch catalyst [9]. In order to transform cobalt-based solids to active FT catalysts, H2 treatment at temperatures between 200 and 450 °C is required to preserve their metallic state during the FTS [10]. In contrast, the activation options of iron-based catalysts are more complex: they can be activated with CO [11], H2 [12], or synthesis gas [13]. Moreover, during the pretreatment step and even during the FTS, Fe-based catalysts can undergo several phase transformations [14]. Hence, the nature of the final phase(s) after pretreatment, or rather the most stable phase(s) under FTS conditions, determines the performance of the catalyst [12,15]. T. Herranz et al. [16] demonstrate that after pretreated of iron oxide catalysts, which content the hematite, with H2, CO, and H2/CO the material was transformed into different phases. The Fe oxide phases modification in metallic iron only was validated when the pretreatment was carried out with hydrogen. However, iron carbide, mainly cementite, was formed with CO (pure or diluted) pretreatments. In contrast, the Hägg carbide, rather than the cementite carbide, was formed when the pretreatment was performed with syngas [17,18]. In the FTS, the so-called "self-organisation" of the catalyst is also a phenomenon that has a major impact on its performance. This process has been known for a long time, but it is difficult to investigate. The Schulz group [12] developed methods for time-resolved product analysis using a kinetic model of non-trivial surface polymerisation. Reaction probabilities of chemisorbed intermediates were calculated as a function of time and carbon number, species at different reaction conditions, and catalyst properties. The findings were used to elucidate the principles of "self-organisation". A frequent observation is the formation of an active phase at the beginning of the reaction. This was explained by carburization or surface reconstruction and is often associated with a change in the selectivity of iron-containing catalysts. The authors also investigated the time dependence of product formation in connection with the change in catalyst composition. Using ex situ X-ray diffraction and Mössbauer spectroscopy, they were able to prove that in the case of Fe, the active iron carbide forms during the reaction, with a continuous decrease of α-Fe content while the FTS activity increases at the same time. However, the effect of the variation of activation treatment conditions on the formation of different species and their abundance has not yet been described for this catalyst. A study on this should enable the identification of an optimal activation process for the FTO. These points are addressed in the present work. The tests were carried out on an already described FeAlCuK catalyst [12], which is still considered the benchmark for olefin formation via FTS. The aim is to show the importance of a suitable pretreatment in the CO2-FTO and to achieve a certain sensitisation regarding this process step. To achieve this, the catalyst was pretreated with H2 (pure and diluted H2 at different contact times and temperatures), synthesis gas (H2/CO = 3) or directly with reaction feed CO2/H2/N2, and the type of bulk and surface species formed in each case were determined. The characterization results were compared with activity measurements. We wanted to answer the question how activation with different atmospheres affects the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. In addition, it was interesting to look at the active phases that form during the pretreatment of the catalysts and whether they are stable or reorganise during the reaction. The catalysts were thus characterized ex and in situ using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy and XPS after each activation treatment. Mössbauer spectroscopy was used to obtain information about their structure after activation and reaction. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Following the procedure reported in [12], the mixed oxide 100Fe:13Al:10Cu:25 K (factors correspond to the weight ratios) was prepared by coprecipitation from the hot aqueous solution of the metal nitrates (Sigma Aldrich, 99 %) by rapid addition of an equivalent molar NH3 solution. The resulting solid was promoted with potassium using an aqueous solution of KNO3 (Merck, 99 %). After impregnation, the sample was dried in air at 100 °C for 5 h and calcined in air at 400 °C for 5 h (heating rate 3.3 K/min). 2.2 Physico-chemical characterisation The changes in the catalyst structure caused by the pretreatments were initially analysed using various ex and in situ techniques such as XRD, Raman and XPS. The pretreatment of catalyst before ex and in situ analyses was made with the same gas compositions as for catalytic tests at the same temperature (H2, H2/CO2/InG and H2/CO/InG, where InG mean “inert gas"). The specific surface area and porosity of the materials were calculated from the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms recorded at −196 °C using a BELSORP-mini II (BEL Japan Inc.) surface area and pore size analyser. Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed for 2 h at 250 °C in vacuum. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation for the N2 relative pressure range of 0.05 < p/p0 < 0.30. The pore size distribution was determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method from the desorption branch of the isotherms. Ambient and non-ambient XRD powder patterns were recorded on a Stoe Stadi P transmission diffractometer equipped with a DECTRIs Mythen2 1 K detector applying Ge(111) monochromatized Mo Kα1 radiation (50 kV, 40 mA, 0.70930 Å). In situ XRD experiments were conducted using a STOE HT2-in situ oven. An internal standard (25 wt% SiO2 (α-quartz), BCR reference material 70, Nr 0749) was added for sample adjustment and position correction purposes. Obtained material was pressed to pellets, crushed, and sieved (100–150 µm fraction) and filled into a capillary reactor (outer diameter of 2 mm, inner diameter of 1 mm) with a bed height of about 6 mm. The catalyst bed in the quartz glass capillary was fixed between quartz wool layers located in the top and bottom reactor positions. For experiments under H2 and H2/CO2/InG (3:1:1) (10 ml/min), the capillary was placed into the oven and heated to 500 °C (5 K/min). Diffraction data were collected after each 50 K step and 1 min equilibration. In case of H2/CO/InG (3:1:16) (10 ml/min) the sample was heated to 250 °C under He (10 ml/min). After switching to reactive feed, data acquisition was performed isothermally over a time period of 4 h with a time resolution of 10 min followed by heating to 400 °C under He without changing the total gas flow. The individual gas flows were set by mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst). The applied temperature correction function was received by observation of well-known phase transitions (AgNO3, KClO4, Ag2SO4, SiO2, K2SO4, K2CrO4, WO3, and BaCO3). Spend catalyst, after using in FTS reaction around 15 h, was also analysed. Raman spectroscopy. In situ Raman experiments were used to monitor the restructuring of the catalysts during the pretreatment step. Raman spectra were obtained using a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope equipped with a 633 nm air-cooled He-Ne laser. The laser beam was focused on the sample by a ×20 objective with a laser power of maximum 1.7 mW to avoid the damaging effect of high laser power. The investigations were performed using a Linkam reaction cell, which acts as a fixed-bed flow reactor. The ceramic reactor was filled with about 50 mg of the catalyst which leads to a filling height of approximately 4 mm. All gases were dosed by mass flow controllers. For the reduction experiments the precursors were exposed to H2 (10 ml/min), CO2/H2/InG (2/6/38 ml/min) and CO/H2/InG (2/6/38 ml/min) with varying temperatures (250–500 °C). Spectra were collected at defined temperature or duration of exposure, respectively. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurements were performed in a Micromeritics 3-Flex device with a quartz tube reactor and a thermal conductivity detector for quantification. Around 100 mg of the samples was loaded into the reactor and pretreated at 300 °C (20 K/min) under a flow of Ar (50 ml/min) for 30 min to remove any adsorbed species from the surface of the samples. Afterwards, the sample was cooled to r.t. under Ar flow. Then, the flow was changed to 30 ml/min 5 % CO/H2/InG and the sample was then ramped to 400 °C at a heating rate of 10 K/min and the temperature was held for 30 min. The reduction peaks were recorded with temperature. The same procedure was repeated up to 600 °C using other gas mixture H2/CO2/InG or only with pure CO and H2 gases. Pseudo in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed in a laboratory Near Ambient Pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy system (NAP-XPS, SPECS Surface Nano Analysis GmbH, Germany). The setup is equipped with a differentially pumped Phoibos 150 electron energy analyser and a monochromated Al Kα radiation source (E = 1486.6 eV) operated at 70 W and 15 kV. The system is connected to a High-Pressure Cell (HPC 20, SPECS Surface Nano Analysis GmbH, Germany) which offers sample heating by a halogen lamp (up to 800 °C) and is equipped with 4 mass flow controllers (MFC’s) at the gas inlet and a manual back pressure regulator (Swagelok, USA) at the outlet. The powder samples are pressed on a stainless-steel sample plate using a laboratory press with 5 mm diameter and a load of about 1 t. Temperature is monitored by a thermocouple on the sample plate pressed to the sample surface. For the current experiments the calcined sample was measured under UHV conditions before (calcined) and after the reduction treatment in H2 at 400 °C for 4 h as well as after a second reduction at 500 °C for 30 min in the HPC at atmospheric pressure. After heating with 20 K/min in H2 to 400 °C, temperature was kept constant for 4 h, followed by cooling to room temperature in N2. For the subsequent reduction the sample was heated with 20 K/min in N2 to 400 °C before the gas was switched to H2 and the temperature increased to 500 °C and kept constant for 30 min. Then the sample was cooled again in N2 to room temperature. After each reduction the sample was transferred without air contact under vacuum to the measurement chamber. For a second experiment the calcined sample was reduced in with H2/CO2 = 3 at 400 °C for 4 h in the HPC at atmospheric pressure followed by a cool down in N2. After reaching room temperature, the sample was transferred under vacuum without air contact to the measurement chamber. 2.2.1 Mössbauer spectra 57Fe Mössbauer measurements were performed by a spectrometer (Wissenschaftliche Elektronik GmbH, Germany) operating in constant-acceleration mode. Transmission Mössbauer spectra were measured at room temperature with 1024 channels analyser, 57Co/Rh isotope with activity of 15 mCi. The parameters of hyperfine interactions of spectral components were determined by computer fitting with Lorentzian line shapes using the fitting program NORMOS, based on the least squares method. These parameters are isomer shift (δ) relative to α-Fe, quadrupole shift (2ε)/quadrupole splitting (Δ), and effective hyperfine magnetic field (Bhf). Line widths (Г) and component relative areas (A) were also calculated. The calculated errors for δ, 2ε, Δ, and Г are ±0.01 mm/s and for Bhf is ± 0.1 T. 2.3 Pre-treatment and reaction conditions The samples were tested in CO2 hydrogenation reaction in a fixed-bed reactor at 400°C, pressure of 3 MPa, and syngas feed with molar ratio H2/CO2 3:1. The reactor temperature was measured with a type K thermocouple positioned in the catalyst bed. The reactor was mounted in a furnace equipped with a PID temperature controller. All downstream lines were kept at 150 °C. The flow rates were set with Bronkhorst mass flow controllers. The calcined catalyst (200 mg, 0.3–0.4 mm particle size) was diluted with SiO2 (approx. 2.0 g, 0.3–0.4 mm particle size) to avoid hot spots. Before exposing to reaction conditions, the as-prepared catalysts were activated in situ at different conditions: i) H2 flow rate (20 ml/min) at 500 °C for 4 h. ii) H2/Ar flow (ratio H2/Ar of 3, 30 ml/min) at 400 °C for 12 h to apply the pretreatment from [12]. iii) H2/CO flow (ratio H2/CO of 3, 30 ml/min) at 250 °C for 4 h. This reduction with syngas was carried out at relatively low temperatures to avoid coking of the catalyst due to product degradation and to limit the deposition of surface carbon by the Boudouard reaction. iv) Without preliminary activation – the catalyst was directly contacted with feed at the selected reaction condition, i.e., molar ratio CO2/H2/N2 ratio in the feed = 1:3:1; pressure = 30 bar, temperature set points = 400–350–300 °C and GHSV = 6000 ml·h−1·g−1. The overall time for each test was 15 h. CO2 conversion and product selectivity were calculated as follows: X CO 2 = 1 − n ̇ CO 2 out n ̇ CO 2 in S i = a i n ̇ i out ∑ j = 1 n a j n ̇ j out Whereby n ̇ i out and n ̇ i in are the molar streams of the i-component at the reactor inlet and outlet. a i = carbon number of the i-component. The feed components (bypass channel) and the reaction products were analysed using a Shimadzu online gas chromatograph 2030 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionisation detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Basic characterisation of the catalyst The results of the ICP analysis and N2 physisorption study of the catalyst prepared by the coprecipitation method are shown in Table 1. As evident from the data, the surface area of catalyst was low. 3.2 Catalyst transformation induced by different gas pretreatments Fe-based catalysts demonstrate several phase transformations during activation and even during CO2-FTS reaction [16–18]. The pretreatment with different gas mixtures and different durations had a strong influence on the nature of the Fe phases and the catalyst activity during the target reaction. The diffraction pattern of our calcined catalyst shows a mostly amorphous structure and therefore a clear identification of the phases is challenging (Figure S1). Crystalline KNO3 was identified beside some low crystalline hematite and the above-mentioned amorphous material. No evidence was found for the presence of crystalline Cu and/or Al-containing phases. To evaluate the phase transformation of the catalyst precursor during activation with different gases (H2, H2/CO/InG or H2/CO2/InG) and temperatures, in situ XRD experiments were executed, at which for all the specimen ex situ data were collected in addition after the experiment ( Fig. 1). When the catalyst was heated from 30 to 500 °C under H2/CO2/InG, different phase changes were observed with increasing temperature. At 300 °C the formation of metallic Fe and a spinel-structured phase can be identified. Also, a minor portion of Cu can be discussed. With increasing temperature, the Bragg peak of metallic Fe decreases due to its conversion to Fe5C2, which are both known to be present under CO2-FTS-conditions [19]. However, ex situ data collection with the recovered sample after standard test and cooling reveals a much more complex diffraction pattern (Figure S2) in which metallic Fe, spinel-like phases (Fe3O4) and carbides (Fe5C2) appear to be the main phases. It should be mentioned that the formation of different spinel-like structured phases (e.g. CuxFe3-xO4) is possible but unfortunately, they are indistinguishable due to almost identical cell constants and the same symmetry settings. In addition, some minor phases such as Fe3C and K2CO3 were identified. Comparable to the treatment under H2/CO2 /InG, the formation of crystalline phases was observed at 300 °C when the experiment is conducted with pure H2. Here, the formation of metallic Fe (cf. 20.05° 2θ) and K2FeO4: (ICDD pdf 01–070–8432) can be stated, where the latter is further reduced as the reflection at 2θ 14.50° disappears when the temperature is further increased to 500 °C In contrast, a distinct identification of elemental Fe or/and FeCx cannot be provided after isothermal treatment under H2/CO-feed after 4 h on stream. Only low crystalline magnetite is formed during this activation method, as also proofed by additional ex situ data collection (Figure S4). If the sample is directly heated in situ to 400 °C under inert gas after H2/CO pretreatment, minor amounts of Fe and FeCx can be identified, especially from ex situ data (Figure S5). 3.2.1 Raman measurements To evaluate the structural changes of the FeAlCuK catalyst during reduction and reaction, Raman spectra were measured in situ before and after pretreatment with H2, H2/CO/InG and H2/CO2/InG mixtures at different temperatures (250, 300, 350, 400, 500 °C). The Raman spectra are generally not well resolved due to the dark colour of the sample, which makes classification difficult. The Raman spectrum of the green catalyst at room temperature under inert He is shown in Fig. 2 as a reference. The sharp peak at 1051 cm−1 is assigned to KNO3 [20], while the broad and intense band around 700 cm−1 can be assigned to CuFe2O4 [21] . Magnetite Fe3O4 shows a characteristic band at 675 cm−1 and weak bands around 540 and 300 cm−1, while maghemite γ-Fe2O3 gave signals at ∼710, 660, 505 and 350 cm−1, so these phases cannot be excluded [22]. Raman bands of hematite (α-Fe2O3) at 605, 404, 290 and 221 cm−1 [23] were not identified. The hematite phase is also not visible in XRD at room temperature, but the Mössbauer spectra of calcined catalysts indicate its presence as shown below. This contrasts with the development of the Raman spectra recorded with time during activation with H2/InG ( Figs. 3A and 3B). After reduction with H2 and variation of the temperature from r.t. to 500 °C (Fig. 3A), no peaks were recognized that correspond to the polymorphs of Fe(III) oxide or oxyhydroxide (e.g. α-Fe2O3, γ-Fe2O3, α-FeOOH and γ-FeOOH). At a temperature of 300 °C, the signals of the source material can still be recognised. Above 300 °C, the peak at 660 cm−1, which could indicate the presence of Fe3O4, was no longer observed (Fig. 3A). Moreover, we pretreated the sample with H2 at 400 °C for 4 h and carried out XRD analyses at different intervals. No further phase formation was seen during the reduction of the sample. This indicates that the transformation of α-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 into metallic α-Fe, which is Raman inactive and not visible, occurs immediately under reductive H2 atmosphere. The formed metallic iron can interact with carbon derived from CO dissociation during the reaction and produce iron carbides among other structural changes. Further in situ Raman experiments were carried out by treating the catalysts with H2/CO/InG and H2/CO2/InG. In particular, the pretreatment with H2/CO2 was carried out to work under real process conditions. The corresponding spectra under CO/H2/InG = 2:6:38 ml/min at 250 °C and specified exposure time are shown in Figs. 4A and 4B. The appearance of the D-band of graphene at 1325 cm−1 and the G-band at 1587 cm−1 became clearly visible 30 min after exposure to the gas mixture. During 60 min, the intensity of both bands increased significantly. An intense additional band at 655 cm−1, which could be assigned to the magnetite phase, has also developed. Since carbon is the most abundant element on the surface, it can be assumed that the catalyst after activation with H2/CO contains a small amount of Fe3O4 phase and an outer amorphous graphitic carbon decoration, except for the dominant carbide (probably Fe5C2) components. The catalyst was further treated with CO2/H2/InG = 2:6:38 ml/min while the temperature was increased stepwise (heating by 20 K/min, 15 min hold at each temperature). The band intensities of KNO3 (1052 cm−1) and those of the starting material (700, 530, 350 cm−1) decreased with increasing temperature and finally disappeared, indicating that these phases are transformed in the H2/CO2/InG atmosphere over time. The formation of Raman silent species (e.g. iron carbides, iron) should not be ignored. At 350 °C, a new band appeared around 650 cm−1, indicating that magnetite may have formed. 3.2.2 TPR measurements The reduction behaviour of the catalyst precursor activated with different gas pre-treatments (pure H2, pure CO, H2/CO/InG and H2/CO2/InG) was analysed using TPR ( Fig. 5). The reduction of iron oxide usually involves three sequential steps of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, Fe3O4 to FeO, and FeO to metallic Fe [23,24], occurring at different temperatures and FeO is thermal stabile up to 570 °C. The reduction temperatures can also vary with the particle size, morphology, and the interaction between iron oxide phase and the other metals in sample. With the addition of Cu, the reduction peaks of Fe catalysts shifted to lower temperature. It suggests that the addition of Cu made the reduction of iron oxide easier [23–25]. The TPR data of the FeAlCuK catalyst pre-treated with H2 show a three-stage reduction. The first peak appeared at 390 °C due to the first reduction step of the oxidic material. However, the start of the reduction can already be recognised at a temperature slightly below 300 °C, which is also consistent with the in situ XRD data. [23]. It is proposed that this peak, associated with the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, may also reflect the catalytic role of metallic Cu in enhancing Fe2O3 reduction, potentially leading to interactions with KNO3 and the formation of KFeO2 or K2FeO2, as supported by similar findings from Witoon et al.l. [24,25]. Between the two main reduction peaks, there appears a shoulder at 420–450 °C. The location of the new reduction peak is at lower temperatures than the iron species (around 600 °C), but at higher temperatures than the usual lowest reduction temperature of CuO (around 300 °C). This fact evidences the role of copper addition in the reduction behavior of iron species and could be attributed to the formation of a mixed phase CuFexOy. Additional continent of K promoter assists incorporation of Cu into the Fe bulk lattice [26]. It is well known that the reduction of CuFe2O4 spinel appearing at lower temperature leads to Cu + Fe2O3, while Fe2O3 is rapidly reduced to metallic Fe [27]. However, no definitive reflection corresponding to the Fe-Cu mixed spinel was observed during in situ XRD study, because either its fraction was too low, or it overlapped with the reduction peaks of Fe and Cu. During the pretreatment with CO, the reduction began at 250 °C. The profile shows two obvious reduction/carburisation peaks. The first peak appeared in the temperature range of 240–280 °C and is related to the reduction of Fe(III) to Fe(II,III) species. These peaks are fully consistent with previous CO-TPR studies of Fe(Cu, K) catalysts [28]. The second peak in the temperature range of 400–525 °C is related to the formation of less active polymeric carbons. In addition, a very small peak was observed at 350 °C. This could be due to the carburisation of the catalyst. However, it is suggested that this might instead result from the decomposition of iron carbides and other carbon species. The signals recorded not only represent CO consumption, but also other gases generated during the experiment. The reduction of the FeAlCuK sample with syngas (H2/CO2/InG) showed a course very similar to the pretreatment of the sample with pure CO, namely a main peak at 200 °C and a second peak at 500 °C. This main peak indicates again the reduction of Fe(III) to Fe(II,III) oxides before subsequent carburisation. Two side peaks were also recorded, indicating further reduction and subsequent carburisation. Furthermore, pretreatment of sample with H2/CO/InG shows the main peak at 250 °C with a shoulder at 200 °C, confirming the dominance of the carbide phase, which is also confirmed by the Raman analysis. During the in situ Raman study (Fig. 4), we detected the formation of Fe3O4 and a small amount of carbide at 350 °C after H2/CO2 treatment of the sample, while pretreatment of the sample with H2/CO shows an immediate formation of mainly of carbides and a small amount of magnetite. 3.2.3 XPS measurements X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out to assess the surface oxidation states and elemental composition. First measurements were carried out with the calcined sample and after pretreatment with pure H2 at 400 °C for 4 h and subsequently at 500 °C for 30 min. An additional measurement with a sample calcined with H2/CO2 = 3 at 400 °C for 4 h was performed to simulate typical reaction conditions ( Fig. 6 and Table 2). The samples were transferred from the pretreatment chamber to the measurement chamber without air contact to avoid reoxidation of the surface. On the ex-situ calcined sample, the elements Fe, Cu, Al, K, C, O, and N can be found, see Table 2 for quantification data. When heating the sample in a H2 atmosphere to 400 °C for 4 h an enrichment of the surface with K, C and Al is observed, whereas the concentrations of Fe and O are decreased. During the second heating step at 500 °C the C and K concentration decreases again whereas the Al concentration rises. These observations indicate a high mobility of K and C species which probably can diffuse from the bulk to the surface and back. It should be noted that the investigation of the surface of a pressed pellet might also influence the observed mobility of different species. However, when performing the reduction in H2/CO2 at 400 °C a strong surface enrichment with C and only to minor extent with K can be observed. Looking at the Cu 2p spectra of the calcined sample in Fig. 6 the Cu 2p3/2 peak can be observed at 934.8 eV together with a strong satellite feature around 942 eV which are characteristic for Cu2+ [29]. Applying different reduction environments leads to a shift of the Cu 2p3/2 peak to 932.8 eV and the disappearance of the satellite features. This indicates a reduction of Cu2+ to Cu1+ or Cu0 which cannot be distinguished due the same binding energy and peak shape [29]. However, the observed binging energies of Cu are shifted towards higher binding energies compared to reference materials which indicates the rather strong interaction with other elements present the catalyst. The Fe 2p spectra of the calcined sample in Fig. 6 shows the Fe 2p3/2 peak at 711.8 eV and a pronounced satellite feature around 720 eV close to the Fe 2p1/2 peak which indicates the oxidation state +3 of iron [29–33]. Applying a reduction at 400 °C for 4 h in H2 changes the Fe 2p spectra strongly with a main Fe 2p3/2 peak at 707.2 eV and a loss of the previously observed satellite feature. This rather sharp indicates a reduction to metallic iron [34]. The rather small shoulder around 711 eV might indicate the presence of oxidic species to minor extent. Even though the Fe surface concentration changes during the subsequent reduction step at 500 °C, see Table 2, the Fe 2p spectrum remains the same. Changing to a reduction treatment in H2/CO2 at 400 °C for 4 h gives completely different results, see Fig. 6. Here the sharp Fe 2p3/2 peak of metallic Fe is accompanied by intensive peaks at higher binding energies up to 711.8 eV indicating the presence of high amounts of oxidic Fe species and only a partial reduction of Fe3+ during this treatment. In this case the observed high surface concentrations of C might protect the oxidic iron species from further reduction. The Al 2p spectra are shown in the supporting information in Figure S6 and overlap with Cu 3p peaks. Even though there is a change in surface concentration of Al during the pretreatment, see Table 2, the observed binding energy remains constant with 74.3 eV and thus indicates a stable Al2O3 phase. Thus, it can be assumed that the main role of Al is to stabilise the catalyst structure. For the Cu 3p peaks a clear shift to lower binding energies can be observed due reduction that was already observed in the Cu 2p region. The rather strong intensity changes of Al 2p and Cu 3p reflect the changes in the surface concentrations of the elements. 3.2.4 Characterization of spent catalysts Fig. 7 and Table 3 present the Mössbauer spectra respective data of the fresh calcined sample and for spent catalysts after FTO reaction, depending on the different activation procedures. The Mössbauer spectra of FeCuAlK calcined at 400 °C over 4 h reveal two Fe3+ components: Calculated sextet (Sx) hyperfine parameters are close to literature data for α-Fe2O3 [35]. Doublet components (Db) appear when such interactions are not registered, and the phases have paramagnetic or superparamagnetic properties. This sample most likely contains iron oxides and/or hydroxides with small particle sizes exhibiting superparamagnetic nature. The obtained hyperfine parameters of spent samples show a distribution of iron between two phases Fe3O4 and χ-Fe5C2. For Fe3O4, both Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions are distributed in the octahedral (A) and tetrahedral [B] sites with respect to oxygen as (Fe3+)[Fe3+Fe2+]O4. They are incorporated at the respective crystallographic positions which are represented by the two components proven by the Mössbauer spectra. Correspondingly, the hyperfine field for the tetrahedral position (Sx1) is Bhf = 49 T due to the Fe3+ ion, whereas octahedral position (Sx2) is Bhf = 46 T due to the average charge of Fe ions which is Fe2.5+, caused by fast electron hopping between Fe2+ and Fe3+. In stoichiometric magnetite, the ratio of areas [B] to [A], calculated from Mössbauer spectra, is 2. In all spent samples the same ratio is obtained, therefore the magnetite is always stoichiometric because of the reducing conditions. Identification of iron carbides is a difficult task due to complexity - their Fe/C ratio varies widely as they usually form small particles (nanoscale) with metastable and distorted crystal structures. In such cases, Mössbauer spectroscopy is also a suitable characterization method [36]. The Mössbauer spectrum of χ-Fe5C2 is usually fitted with three sextets for iron atoms that are in the unit cell in three non-equivalent positions. From the relative intensities of the three sextets considering equal recoil-free factors for the corresponding species, it is possible to determine the respective occupation of these sites by iron. Obtained hyperfine parameters of three sextets Sx3, Sx4 and Sx5 after fitting procedure are in agreement with reported literature [37] which corresponds to the three types of Fe (Fe1, Fe2 and Fe3 in each sample) in the unit cell of χ-Fe5C2 (Hägg carbide). The ratio of magnetite to carbide for samples activated with H2 and H2/CO is similar – one third magnetite and two thirds carbide. However, activation of FeCuAlK with H2/CO2 led to formation of the two phases in approximately equal amounts. Powder X-ray diffraction of the spent catalyst after activation with H2 and 15 h on stream is given in Fig. 8. Within the complex powder pattern spinel-like structured Fe-oixdes and Hägg-Carbide (Fe5C2) is identified as the major components. Also, the formation of paraffine like hydrocarbons deposits can be seen from diffraction data. Comparable to the diffraction pattern collected after in-situ-XRD experiments the identification of Al-containing phases was not possible. According to the results from physical-chemical characterization experiments, it should be emphasized that catalyst pretreatment with different gases affects the formation of active phases of FeCuAlK catalyst. The segregation of surface species, i.e., the enrichment or depletion of species on the surface, is a common phenomenon in multimetallic systems that, among other effects, determines the catalytic activity. We observed this behaviour with variations of Fe, Cu, K, Al, and C contents on the surface of the samples depending on the pretreatment conditions. Comparison of the data after each treatment of the calcined catalyst indicates that each pretreatment step strongly influences the phase composition in a specific way: i) During reduction with H2 at 400 and 500 °C, a different reducibility of Fe and Cu was observed, which influenced the catalyst activity. The phase transition sequence during H2 activation follows Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → Fe, but the CuFe2O4 → Cu + Fe2O3 reduction can also be observed. Probably after treatment with H2 at 500 °C, the α-Fe phase became predominant, and at the same time Cu and Al accumulated on the surface, while the amount of K decreased compared to the sample pretreated with H2 at 400 °C. It is possible that the coexistence of mixed phase (CuFe2O4 or K2FeO4) and α-Fe phases determines the activity at both temperatures. This reduced state seems to play a major role in the formation of more α-Fe during H2 activation at 500 °C and the easy formation of Hägg carbide during CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The presence of copper is important as then Fe3+ can be easily reduced. Potassium acts as promoter, which also causes the phase transformation. In the initial stage of reduction, the role of Cu as a promoter is to loosen the Fe-O bond and facilitate oxygen removal. ii) During activation with H2/CO/InG at 250 °C, the formation of a remarkable fraction of active ꭤ-Fe, which after contact with feed easily was transformed to Hägg carbide χ-Fe5C2. A very small amount of magnetite Fe3O4 will be no excluded. iii) Analysis of FeCuAlK after pretreatment with H2/CO2/InG (simulating typical reaction conditions) shows formation of Fe5C2 phase, which is known as the active phase for the formation of C2-C4 olefins. However, the presence of high amount of Fe3O4 must not be disregarded, as it could irreversibly form under CO2 hydrogenation conditions by oxidizing the iron carbides, which would be a major factor in deactivating the catalyst. 3.3 Catalyst performance CO2 hydrogenation is usually studied at temperatures above 300 °C [24]. Our research focused on the 300–400 °C range. The samples pretreated with various gases showed different activity during the screening at the selected FTO conditions ( Fig. 9). The conversion and selectivity towards light olefins depend on the temperature but also on the pretreatment. Pressure and space velocity were set to 30 bar and 6000 ml·h−1·g−1 in these tests. The CO2 conversion was strongly related to the reaction temperature. The highest CO2 conversion was observed at 400 °C, regardless of the sample pretreatment. However, differences in the desired products distribution became more evident when changing the activation protocol in the order (H2/CO at 250 °C over 4 h) > (H2 at 500 °C over 4 h) > (H2 at 400 °C over 12 h) > (without activation – presented as H2/CO2 in Fig. 9). In general, the H2/CO pretreatment resulted in the most effective catalyst in terms of CO2 conversion and selectivity for light olefins, while the other pretreatments resulted in less active materials. A comparison of the catalytic efficiency of FeCuAlK at the highest reaction temperature of 400 °C shows the following correlations: i) The sample pretreated with H2/CO achieved the highest CO2 conversion (43 %) and the highest selectivity for light olefins (34 %). In addition, lower CO selectivity (14 %) was observed compared to the other results, but the CH4 selectivity was 21 %. ii) When the catalyst was activated with H2 at 500 °C for 4 h, the CO2 conversion was the same as after H2/CO activation, but the selectivity for light olefins decreased to 29 %, while the CO selectivity increased to 17 % and CH4 reached 18 %. iii) Activation with H2 at 400 °C for 12 h also gave the same CO2 conversion but led to a decrease in selectivity for light olefins (26 %), but an increase in selectivity for CO (20 %) and CH4 (20 %). iv) When activated with H2/CO2 at 400 °C for 4 h, the lowest CO2 conversion was observed. The selectivity for light olefins was the same as for the sample activated at 400 °C with H2 for 12 h; whereas the highest selectivity was observed for CO (27 %) and the lowest for CH4 (16.5 %). Interestingly, methane formation was slightly lower without pretreatment. This side reaction is ascribed to Fe3O4, Fe5C2 and Fe2O3, which coexist during the reaction [24]. When the reaction temperature was lowered to 350 °C, the CO2 conversion dropped by about 10 % when the samples were activated with H2 at 500 °C or H2/InG at 400 °C. However, when the sample was activated with H2/CO or not at all, no strong changes in CO2 conversion were detected at this temperature. At 350 °C, the FeAlCuK catalyst activated with H2/CO shows a decrease in the selectivity for alkenes (30.5 %) and higher selectivity for C2-C4 alkanes (10 %) compared to the test at 400 °C. At the same time, the selectivity for CO decreased by 11 % and for CH4 by 14.5 %, while the selectivity for C7+ increased. The highest selectivity was observed at 350 °C on the sample activated in H2 at 500 °C over 4 h: The selectivity for light olefins was 33 %, for C5 14 % and less than 14 % for CH4 and CO, respectively. The same trend in product distribution was observed after activation with H2 at 400 °C for 12 h, but less of the desired light olefins were formed. At the lowest reaction temperature of 300 °C, the conversion of CO2 with FeAlCuK activated with H2 at 400 °C, 500 °C or without activation decreased dramatically, the selectivity for CO increased significantly, while the selectivity for CH4, alkanes and C5-C7 was almost the same as above. The selectivity for olefins decreased significantly. On the contrary, the sample pretreated with H2/CO at 300 °C did not show significant changes in CO2 conversion and CO selectivity. The selectivity for CH4 slightly decreased and that of C7-C12 products increased to 25 %, while the selectivity of the desired olefins also did not change significantly. The pretreatment conditions had a strong effect on the product distribution on FeAlCuK during the FTO reaction and especially on the fraction of light olefins. The CO selectivity after different reduction treatments changed significantly, indicating that the reduction conditions (gas mixture and temperature) have a major influence on the development of the active centres for the water-gas shift reaction. It is assumed that the back reaction (RWGS) is mainly promoted by metal oxides based on a redox cycle via H2 reducing Fe3+ to Fe2+ and CO2 oxidising Fe2+ to form CO. The Fe cation-oxygen pairs at octahedrally coordinated iron positions are supposed to be the active sites for the RWGS reaction with electron hopping between Fe0 and Fe3+ [23]. Since Cu has its specific RWGS activity as well, any additional increase in activity can be attributed to Cu in the FeAlCuK catalyst. Our ex and in situ studies revealed that Cu is incorporated into the Fe lattice as a spinel (CuFe2O4) and this promotes CO2 conversion at the Fe surface. It was shown [23,24,38,39] that Fe-Cu-O in this spinel structure is based on the reduction of Fe3+ ions in octahedrally coordinated sites, which favour the formation of additional oxygen vacancies that facilitate CO2 adsorption and further reaction. Probably the same effects were triggered in our sample. In addition, potassium in FeAlCuK has a similar stimulating effect on the reduction of Fe3+. The effect of these rearrangements’ contribution is visible as the catalyst activity is varied during pretreatment with H2 to the 500 °C. Pretreatment at higher temperature shows higher selectivity for light olefins at the expense of CO selectivity, since additional oxygen vacancies are formed on the catalyst during the reduction at 500 °C (TPR data). In addition, potassium mainly stabilises the surface iron atoms, but also participates in this ion exchange process [23]. This promoter has no influence on the catalyst structure but modulates the adsorption and reduction properties of FeAlCuK. This indicates that the mixed oxide phase Fe-Cu-(K), which is easily reduced to the metallic Fe, together with the α-Fe species acts as one of the active sites during CO2 hydrogenation. From the product distribution (Fig. 9) it can be concluded that during the pretreatment of FeAlCuK with H2/CO at 250 °C for 4 h, the phase transformation and Fe-Cu-K synergism led to the highest catalyst activity; at the same time, it is significantly less selective for CO and shows a 10-fold increase in selectivity for light hydrocarbons (C2-C4) compared to the performance after any other pretreatment. The olefin selectivity was increased due to formation of α-Fe and Fe5C2 as the predominant phase during activation. 4 Conclusions This paper focuses on the influence of the composition of various reducing gas mixtures on the formation of active phase of FeCuAlK, well known as Schultz catalyst for Fe-FTS. We demonstrated the effect of the pre-treatment conditions by comparing the activity and product selectivity. This was accompanied by ex and in situ physical-chemical characterization. Understanding the complex phenomena occurring during the catalyst reduction and the resulting benefits pave the way to improve the catalyst performance. The formation of the active species is important as it strongly depends on the formation of numerous oxygen vacancies on the catalytic surface during reduction. We propose that the FeCuAlK catalyst should be activated in a H2/CO atmosphere at 250 °C for 4 h or with H2 at 500 °C to reach the maximum capacity of such sites before starting the FTO reaction. The reduction with H2/CO led to higher CO2 conversion and the formation of active ꭤ-Fe phase to produce light olefins. The presence of spinel ferrite together with haematite phase and potassium promoter, which modulates the adsorption and reduction properties of the catalyst, leads to a significant improvement in catalytic performance when the sample was reduced with H2 at 500 °C. The iron oxides are reduced to metallic Fe0, some additional α-Fe and iron oxides (Fe3O4 and/or FeO) remain due to the partial reduction of mixed phase (CuFe2O4 or K2FeO4), especially when reducing at 500 °C. Moreover, after studying of spent catalyst with Mössbauer spectroscopy we identify that the ratio of magnetite to carbide for samples activated with H2 and H2/CO is similar - one third magnetite and two thirds carbide. However, direct contact of FeCuAlK with H2/CO2 led to formation of the two phases in approximately equal amounts. This mean that main amount of magnetite (FeO4) generated after H2/CO2 reduction and was then gradually carbonized to χ-Fe5C2. This transformation is confirmed after in- and ex-situ XRD, Raman and XPS research. Eventually, the magnetite (Fe3O4) phase was changed to χ -Fe3C, which is not an active species for CO2 hydrogenation. To avoid this transformation, we need preliminary activation of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: To improve the CO2-to-light olefin process in terms of economics, efficient catalysts are essential to maximize the yield. Our research was carried out on FeAlCuK, which is still considered as a benchmark for olefin formation via CO2 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS). Nevertheless, the effect of various activation conditions on the formation of desired active species and final activity of this catalyst has not been described in literature to date. We studied the pretreatment by varying both the reduction gas and temperature. The catalyst was pretreated with pure H2 or synthesis gas (H2/CO = 3) to identify the bulk and surface species formed in each case. We demonstrate that the FeCuAlK catalyst should be activated in a H2/CO atmosphere at 250 °C for 4 h before the test at typical FTS reaction conditions to reach maximum productivity. The reduction with H2/CO led to the formation of active Fe5C2 and Fe3O4 phases producing a high fraction of light olefins at higher CO2 conversion. The role of promoters K and Cu was also investigated. Selectivity for desired C2-C4 olefins increased by 10 % compared to catalysts which were used directly in FTS without preliminary activation. Characterization with ex and in situ powder X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, and XPS after each activation treatment as well as Mössbauer spectroscopy revealed a strong impact of gas nature on the phase composition which was correlated with the performance.
